Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
Does the concept of a/an Polynomial Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Canonical Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Canonical Homomorphism specifically involves the polynomial ring R[X] and its transformation into another polynomial ring R/(p)[X] through the process of reducing coefficients modulo a prime element p. The concept of a Polynomial Ring is essential here because it defines what R[X] and R/(p)[X] are, which are the domains and codomains of the canonical homomorphism. Without understanding or defining what a polynomial ring is, the operation of the canonical homomorphism, which acts on elements of these rings, would not make sense. Therefore, the concept of a Polynomial Ring is necessary for the definition of a Canonical Homomorphism to be meaningful and complete.
